awd_titl_txt: CSR:SmartChainDB - Enabling Smart Marketplaces With A Scalable Semantically-Enhanced Blockchain Platform
awd_abstract_narration:
Production of goods and services is becoming increasingly distributed and decentralized, with organizations often requiring partnerships with other organizations to achieve their goals. However, in some domains such as digital manufacturing, stakes can be very high (e.g. aircraft manufacturing). Consequently, rapid and organic formation of partnerships is often not possible because the process of establishing trust between partners is laborious, time-consuming and expensive - the so-called "trust tax". In this environment, overcoming the trust-tax barrier is a significant impediment to market participation for newer or smaller organizations. The SmartChainDB project will investigate the foundations and implementation of middleware for achieving the vision of "smart digital marketplaces" where partnerships between service organizations are brokered digitally rather than with physical interactions. It aligns with the NSF Harnessing Data for 21st Century Science and Engineering Big Ideas vision and can serve to improve US competitiveness in advanced manufacturing. 


The vision is to build on the general properties of the present-day technology of trust (blockchains) and develop necessary extensions for enabling (i) declarative descriptions of both service provider capabilities and service requestor needs; (ii) a data-driven trust model based on data and metadata about organizations, their assets, capabilities and performance records; (iii) automatic matching and trust-based validation of service providers' bids to requests for service; and (iv) confidentiality and privacy of sensitive parts of partner transactions and collaborations. Key design challenges will be supporting these goals while achieving scalability, performance, and quality.  The SmartChainDB project will deepen our insights in the area of software systems for digital trust. It will provide inter-disciplinary training opportunities for the next-generation of computer scientists and industrial systems engineers. It also has the potential to broaden market participation in various industries by significantly reducing the trust-tax burden, ensuring a more level playing field for smaller and startup organizations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Blockchains facilitate transparent and auditable transactions between parties without centralized authorities, offering significant potential for complex transaction environments such as supply chains. However, current blockchain transaction models are often too rudimentary to support sophisticated business needs. Existing extension mechanisms require specialized software development skills for implementing and verifying smart contracts, which are prone to costly errors and have opaque behavior semantics to the blockchain engine, limiting automatic optimization. Additionally, unique privacy requirements during transactions are not straightforward to achieve using existing transaction models, negatively affecting both usability and performance.

This project advanced blockchain technology through three primary contributions:

First, we investigated and developed techniques for generalizing blockchain transaction models by introducing concepts such as "typing" for blockchain transactions and "nested blockchain transactions." We implemented these concepts in SmartChainDB, our extension of the open-source BigChainDB platform, focusing on decentralized manufacturing marketplaces. Our evaluation framework demonstrated superior performance in latency, throughput, and ease-of-use compared to equivalent smart contract implementations. Additionally, we developed a semantic event model enabling suppliers to detect relevant purchaser events, compensating for the limited search and query capabilities inherent in blockchain systems.

Second, we addressed the challenge of privacy in marketplace transactions by developing a formal framework for "private matching" between requestors and suppliers. This framework is particularly crucial in manufacturing contexts where protecting competitive advantages is essential while maintaining blockchain transparency. We established formal cryptographic proofs of security using the Universally Composable framework, devising an ideal functionality that captures private matching requirements. The resulting implementation, integrated into SmartChainDB's signature framework, provides strong privacy guarantees while remaining extensible to various threat models.

Third, we developed methods to enable decentralized marketplace customers to access large-capacity manufacturing nodes over cryptographically secure networks. Traditional Ethereum-based ecosystems, designed primarily for financial transactions, are inefficient for large manufacturing data streams. We designed and implemented a hybrid blockchain architecture incorporating efficient communication protocols and blockchain oracles, enabling the transfer and immutable storage of large manufacturing data streams onto global BigChainDB nodes. This architecture bypasses Ethereum transaction fees for data-intensive operations. Furthermore, we developed a machine learning-based time series inference model for Ethereum gas price forecasting, enabling judicious assignment of gas price limits and optimizing transaction costs.

The project contributed significantly to education and workforce development:

  • Supported and mentored 5 Ph.D. students, including two female students
  • Facilitated curriculum expansion through a new seminar class covering data management and security topics, co-taught by project PIs
  • Enabled co-advised Masters thesis and Independent Study projects
  • Disseminated findings through prestigious venues including IEEE Blockchain, ACM Distributed Event-Based Systems, International Workshop on Cryptocurrencies and Blockchain Technology, IEEE Web Intelligence, and domain-specific journals like Procedia Manufacturing

This research advances both the theoretical understanding and practical implementation of blockchain technology in complex transaction environments, particularly manufacturing marketplaces, while maintaining rigorous security and privacy guarantees.
